comment_text.mn128:1.1: This discourse offers a unique insight into the Buddha’s own meditative development. The “corruptions” of the title are the subtle mental flaws that undermine meditation when it is on the brink of absorption. | This discourse and MN 31 appear to be influenced by Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3, a famous dialogue where an unusually reluctant Yājñavalkya is repeatedly pressed by King Janaka to reveal the true nature of a person’s light.
comment_text.mn128:2.1: This is in reference to the notorious quarrel at Kosambī, also referred to at MN 48:2.1. The events are detailed in the Vinaya at Kd 10.
comment_text.mn128:3.4: While both here and at MN 48 we see the Buddha intervening to settle the conflict, here he goes to them, while there he summons them to him; and the ensuing course of the sutta is quite different.
comment_text.mn128:6.1: These verses are also found in the Vinaya account at Kd 10:3.1.3 and the Kosambiya Jātaka at Ja 428:1.1.
comment_text.mn128:6.9: These four verses are shared with Dhp 3–6.
comment_text.mn128:6.21: This verse is found in the same context at Dhp 6, and in different contexts in Thag 4.3:1.1 and Thag 8.1:5.1.
comment_text.mn128:6.22: Yamāmese is reflexive first person plural imperative of yamati, “let us restrain ourselves”, cf. SN 10.6:3.1: pāṇesu ca saṁyamāmase (“Let us restrain ourselves regarding living creatures”).
comment_text.mn128:7.1: “Child salt-miners” is bālakaloṇakāra (cf. loṇakāradārako at AN 4.188:5.3). Children are used to mine salt in India to this day.
comment_text.mn128:7.2: Bhagu was a leading Sakyan who went forth along with Bhaddiya, Anuruddha, Ānanda, Kimbila, Devadatta, and Upāli (Kd 17:1.4.1). He is known from his ardent striving described in his verses at Thag 4.2, and is listed with other renowned mendicants at MN 68:2.2. | After the conflict at Kosambī, the Buddha sought the company of his fellow Sakyans; first Bhagu, then the three Sakyans below. | Another Bhagu was one of the ancient Vedic seers, while yet another was a contemporary of Sāṇavāsī around the time of the Second Council (Kd 8:24.6.6).
comment_text.mn128:8.1: This park was in Ceti, not far from Kosambī. A Prācīnavaṁśa was a hall or shed built for the ritual, with bamboo (vaṁśa) rafters running easterly (prācīna; Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 3.1.1.6 and Eggeling’s note). | Apart from the setting, the following passage is identical with MN 31:2.1ff., down as far as the discussion on meditation; see that sutta for notes. The current sutta is the original narrative context (see note on MN 31:6.1).
comment_text.mn128:8.2: The park keeper was evidently not Buddhist, as he was responsible for a Vedic ritual site.
comment_text.mn128:8.4: MS and BJT read mahāsamaṇa here, whereas PTS and parallel passages at MN 31:3.4 and Kd 10:4.2.3 have simply samaṇa. Mahāsamaṇa (“great ascetic”) is a rare epithet of the Buddha found mainly in the Vinaya. It is unlikely the park keeper would have kept him out knowing who he really was.
comment_text.mn128:14.7: For hatthavilaṅghaka (“lending a hand up”) see MN 125:9.2.
comment_text.mn128:15.2: As at MN 31:10.3ff., Anuruddha must be prodded to reveal the full extent of his meditation prowess. The form of both suttas parallels Yājñavalkya’s reticence to answer Janaka. In addition, the theme also echoes the Upaniṣad, for Janaka asks what is a person’s light (kiṁjyotirayaṁ puruṣa, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 4.3.2). Yājñavalkya answers that it is simply the sun. When pressed further, he admits it might be the moon, then fire, or even speech, for you can make it home in the dark when someone is calling. All these things—sun, moon, fire, speech—are worshipped in the Vedic tradition as external manifestations of divinity. He only reluctantly admits that a person’s true light is their Self, made of consciousness, the light in the heart. This is the same Self referred to above in the phrase, “whose nature is to desire only the self”. | The Vedantic commentator Śaṅkara, on a verse of the same chapter (4.3.7), discusses at length Buddhist objections to his doctrine. Thus the Buddhist text looks back to the Upaniṣad, while the commentary to that same Upaniṣad looks to Buddhism.
comment_text.mn128:15.3: The key terms here are “perceive” (sañjānāma), “light” (obhāsa), and “vision of forms” (dassanañca rūpānaṁ). Variations of these are common terms for the visions seen in meditation (eg. DN 9:14.2, MN 77:22.2, MN 121:5.4). The “light” is the radiance that indicates freedom from defilements, while the “forms” may be the various phenomena that one in such a meditation might see. In particular this refers to the power of clairvoyance (dibbacakkhu), in which Anuruddha was later declared foremost (AN 1.192:1.1). See the discussion in the previous sutta (MN 127:10.1) and also eg. MN 32:6.6, SN 9.6:1.2 AN 3.130:1.3, and AN 8.46:1.3.
comment_text.mn128:15.5: Below, the Buddha investigates by way of “cause and reason” (MN 128:16.5), hence the commentary explains nimitta here as “basis” (kāraṇa; for similar senses see MN 12:23.1, SN 48.40:1.6, AN 3.102:1.2). | Confusingly, in the previous sentence we have “light and vision of forms”, but this is not nimitta, which does not have this meaning in early texts. For related contexts, see DN 11:80.12, DN 33:1.9.27, MN 5:6.1, MN 20:2.1, MN 36:45.6, MN 44:12.3, AN 3.19:2.3, AN 4.14:4.2, AN 6.27:7.1, and AN 9.35:1.11. | Anuruddha learned his lesson, for at MN 68:6.2 he explains how hindrances prevent absorption.
comment_text.mn128:16.3: This refers to a stage in the development of meditation when immersion is not properly consolidated. It is a delicate phase, where familiar hindrances appear in subtle ways, which can nonetheless be an obstacle for absorption. Below I give my understanding of these meditation issues and how to deal with them.
comment_text.mn128:16.7: When immersion is not consolidated, even the slightest uncertainty as to how to proceed can disturb the meditation. Doubt can also arise regarding whether the visions seen in meditation are real. This can be counteracted by determining one’s meditation at the beginning. | These three sentences use grammatical tense very precisely: an event is recalled (in past tense); a timeless principle is inferred (in present tense); and a resolution is made (in future tense).
comment_text.mn128:17.6: The mind drifts from the meditation. At this subtle level, the mind may not be wandering or lost, but merely focusing imprecisely.
comment_text.mn128:18.3: Practicing to this level takes time, and any meditator will experience drowsiness at some point, even if it is merely a lack of fully clear energy. It is counteracted by rapture (pīti), which uplifts and inspires the mind.
comment_text.mn128:19.5: While “terror” might feel like an overly-strong rendering for chambhitatta in this context, this example shows what it means. At this point the mind is amplified, so that even small reactions can quickly get out of hand. The Buddha explains more about this point in his meditation at MN 4:20.1.
comment_text.mn128:20.3: This can happen when the mind is starting to coalesce, and one is excited that absorption is near. To address this, a meditator might reflect on the importance of patience, and focus more on developing tranquility in the fundamental stages of meditation.
comment_text.mn128:21.3: All meditators experience discomfort when sitting for long periods of time. To deal with this, a meditator should first get as comfortable as they reasonably can, then develop pleasure in the body. Anuruddha overcame pain in the body through the four kinds of mindfulness meditation (SN 52.10:2.1).
comment_text.mn128:22.3: Pushing too hard at the meditation, the body and mind can become over-wired with energy. To find balance, a meditator needs to relax and draw back from the meditation just a little.
comment_text.mn128:23.3: The opposite of the previous, here the mind subtly falls back from the meditation too far. They are not exactly drowsy, but the mind lacks the keenness to go deeper. In response, a meditator needs to apply the mind a little more strongly to the meditation.
comment_text.mn128:24.3: The meditator yearns for higher spiritual realizations, as at Thag 19.1:16.1 or AN 4.159:6.7. This is a wholesome motivation, but at this point it can disturb the meditation.
comment_text.mn128:25.3: Diversity can arise through the activity of the senses, or through the variety of “forms” seen by the meditator. Either way, the mind must be settled to find true oneness.
comment_text.mn128:26.6: The “forms” seen in meditation can be enticing and fascinating, appearing as glimpses of other realms, impressions of the presence of beings, or images of past lives. If the meditator pays too much attention to them, they lose focus on the meditation itself.
comment_text.mn128:28.9: This shows how nimitta has a causal sense. Manasikāra (“focus”) is typically used of paying attention to causes.
comment_text.mn128:31.4: This threefold presentation of the process of absorption focuses on vitakka (“placing the mind”) and vicāra (“keeping it connected”), looking closely at how they cease (see also DN 33:1.10.121, DN 34:1.4.7, SN 43.3:1.2, and AN 8.63:3.1). The standard jhāna formula focuses more on the refinement of feelings, from which perspective the first two stages of immersion here fall under the “rapture and bliss born of seclusion”, while only the third qualifies as “rapture and bliss born of immersion”. Thus Analayo describes the two descriptions as “complementary perspectives on the same process of deepening concentration” (Comparative Study, vol. ii, pg. 739, note 263).

root_text.mn128:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kosambiyaṁ viharati ghositārāme.
root_text.mn128:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena kosambiyaṁ bhikkhū bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti.
root_text.mn128:3.1: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi. Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn128:3.2: “idha, bhante, kosambiyaṁ bhikkhū bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti.
root_text.mn128:3.3: Sādhu, bhante, bhagavā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkamatu anukampaṁ upādāyā”ti.
root_text.mn128:4.1: Atha kho bhagavā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
root_text.mn128:4.2: “alaṁ, bhikkhave, mā bhaṇḍanaṁ, mā kalahaṁ, mā viggahaṁ, mā vivādan”ti.
root_text.mn128:4.3: Evaṁ vutte, aññataro bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn128:4.6: appossukko, bhante, bhagavā diṭṭhadhammasukhavihāraṁ anuyutto viharatu;
root_text.mn128:4.7: mayametena bhaṇḍanena kalahena viggahena vivādena paññāyissāmā”ti.

root_text.mn128:5.1: Atha kho bhagavā pubbaṇhasamayaṁ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya kosambiṁ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
root_text.mn128:5.2: Kosambiyaṁ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto senāsanaṁ saṁsāmetvā pattacīvaramādāya ṭhitakova imā gāthā abhāsi:
root_text.mn128:6.40: Eko care na ca pāpāni kayirā,
root_text.mn128:7.1: Atha kho bhagavā ṭhitakova imā gāthā bhāsitvā yena bālakaloṇakāragāmo tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.mn128:7.2: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā bhagu bālakaloṇakāragāme viharati.
root_text.mn128:7.3: Addasā kho āyasmā bhagu bhagavantaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
root_text.mn128:7.4: Disvāna āsanaṁ paññapesi udakañca pādānaṁ dhovanaṁ.
root_text.mn128:7.7: Āyasmāpi kho bhagu bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
root_text.mn128:7.8: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho āyasmantaṁ bhaguṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
root_text.mn128:7.9: “kacci, bhikkhu, khamanīyaṁ, kacci yāpanīyaṁ, kacci piṇḍakena na kilamasī”ti?
root_text.mn128:7.10: “Khamanīyaṁ bhagavā, yāpanīyaṁ bhagavā, na cāhaṁ, bhante, piṇḍakena kilamāmī”ti.
root_text.mn128:7.11: Atha kho bhagavā āyasmantaṁ bhaguṁ dhammiyā kathāya sandassetvā samādapetvā samuttejetvā sampahaṁsetvā uṭṭhāyāsanā yena pācīnavaṁsadāyo tenupasaṅkami.
root_text.mn128:8.1: Tena kho pana samayena āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo pācīnavaṁsadāye viharanti.
root_text.mn128:8.2: Addasā kho dāyapālo bhagavantaṁ dūratova āgacchantaṁ.
root_text.mn128:9.1: Assosi kho āyasmā anuruddho dāyapālassa bhagavatā saddhiṁ mantayamānassa.
root_text.mn128:10.1: Atha kho āyasmā anuruddho yenāyasmā ca nandiyo yenāyasmā ca kimilo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmantañca nandiyaṁ āyasmantañca kimilaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn128:10.3: Atha kho āyasmā ca anuruddho āyasmā ca nandiyo āyasmā ca kimilo bhagavantaṁ paccuggantvā
root_text.mn128:10.4: eko bhagavato pattacīvaraṁ paṭiggahesi, eko āsanaṁ paññapesi, eko pādodakaṁ upaṭṭhapesi.
root_text.mn128:10.7: Tepi kho āyasmanto bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu.
root_text.mn128:10.8: Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho āyasmantaṁ anuruddhaṁ bhagavā etadavoca:
root_text.mn128:10.9: “kacci vo, anuruddhā, khamanīyaṁ, kacci yāpanīyaṁ, kacci piṇḍakena na kilamathā”ti?
root_text.mn128:10.10: “Khamanīyaṁ bhagavā, yāpanīyaṁ bhagavā, na ca mayaṁ, bhante, piṇḍakena kilamāmā”ti.
root_text.mn128:11.1: “Kacci pana vo, anuruddhā, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṁ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharathā”ti?
root_text.mn128:11.2: “Taggha mayaṁ, bhante, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṁ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharāmā”ti.
root_text.mn128:11.3: “Yathā kathaṁ pana tumhe, anuruddhā, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṁ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharathā”ti?
root_text.mn128:12.4: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, imesu āyasmantesu mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ āvi ceva raho ca,
root_text.mn128:12.5: mettaṁ vacīkammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ āvi ceva raho ca,
root_text.mn128:12.6: mettaṁ manokammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn128:12.8: ‘yannūnāhaṁ sakaṁ cittaṁ nikkhipitvā imesaṁyeva āyasmantānaṁ cittassa vasena vatteyyan’ti.
root_text.mn128:12.9: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, sakaṁ cittaṁ nikkhipitvā imesaṁyeva āyasmantānaṁ cittassa vasena vattāmi.
root_text.mn128:12.10: Nānā hi kho no, bhante, kāyā, ekañca pana maññe cittan”ti.
root_text.mn128:12.16: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, imesu āyasmantesu mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ āvi ceva raho ca,
root_text.mn128:12.17: mettaṁ vacīkammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ āvi ceva raho ca,
root_text.mn128:12.18: mettaṁ manokammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn128:12.20: ‘yannūnāhaṁ sakaṁ cittaṁ nikkhipitvā imesaṁyeva āyasmantānaṁ cittassa vasena vatteyyan’ti.
root_text.mn128:12.21: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, sakaṁ cittaṁ nikkhipitvā imesaṁyeva āyasmantānaṁ cittassa vasena vattāmi.
root_text.mn128:12.22: Nānā hi kho no, bhante, kāyā, ekañca pana maññe cittanti.
root_text.mn128:12.23: Evaṁ kho mayaṁ, bhante, samaggā sammodamānā avivadamānā khīrodakībhūtā aññamaññaṁ piyacakkhūhi sampassantā viharāmā”ti.
root_text.mn128:13.2: Kacci pana vo, anuruddhā, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharathā”ti?
root_text.mn128:14.1: “Taggha mayaṁ, bhante, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharāmā”ti.
root_text.mn128:14.2: “Yathā kathaṁ pana tumhe, anuruddhā, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharathā”ti?
root_text.mn128:14.3: “Idha, bhante, amhākaṁ yo paṭhamaṁ gāmato piṇḍāya paṭikkamati, so āsanāni paññapeti, pānīyaṁ paribhojanīyaṁ upaṭṭhāpeti, avakkārapātiṁ upaṭṭhāpeti.
root_text.mn128:14.4: Yo pacchā gāmato piṇḍāya paṭikkamati—sace hoti bhuttāvaseso, sace ākaṅkhati, bhuñjati; no ce ākaṅkhati, appaharite vā chaḍḍeti apāṇake vā udake opilāpeti—
root_text.mn128:14.5: so āsanāni paṭisāmeti, pānīyaṁ paribhojanīyaṁ paṭisāmeti, avakkārapātiṁ dhovitvā paṭisāmeti, bhattaggaṁ sammajjati.
root_text.mn128:14.6: Yo passati pānīyaghaṭaṁ vā paribhojanīyaghaṭaṁ vā vaccaghaṭaṁ vā rittaṁ tucchaṁ so upaṭṭhāpeti.
root_text.mn128:14.7: Sacassa hoti avisayhaṁ, hatthavikārena dutiyaṁ āmantetvā hatthavilaṅghakena upaṭṭhāpema, na tveva mayaṁ, bhante, tappaccayā vācaṁ bhindāma.
root_text.mn128:14.8: Pañcāhikaṁ kho pana mayaṁ, bhante, sabbarattiṁ dhammiyā kathāya sannisīdāma.
root_text.mn128:14.9: Evaṁ kho mayaṁ, bhante, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharāmā”ti.
root_text.mn128:15.2: Atthi pana vo, anuruddhā, evaṁ appamattānaṁ ātāpīnaṁ pahitattānaṁ viharataṁ uttari manussadhammā alamariyañāṇadassanaviseso adhigato phāsuvihāro”ti?
root_text.mn128:15.3: “Idha mayaṁ, bhante, appamattā ātāpino pahitattā viharantā obhāsañceva sañjānāma dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:15.4: So kho pana no obhāso nacirasseva antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ;
root_text.mn128:16.1: “Taṁ kho pana vo, anuruddhā, nimittaṁ paṭivijjhitabbaṁ.
root_text.mn128:16.2: Ahampi sudaṁ, anuruddhā, pubbeva sambodhā anabhisambuddho bodhisattova samāno obhāsañceva sañjānāmi dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:16.3: So kho pana me obhāso nacirasseva antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:16.5: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yena me obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānan’ti?
root_text.mn128:16.7: ‘vicikicchā kho me udapādi, vicikicchādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:16.8: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:16.9: Sohaṁ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissatī’ti.
root_text.mn128:17.1: So kho ahaṁ, anuruddhā, appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto obhāsañceva sañjānāmi dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:17.2: So kho pana me obhāso nacirasseva antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.

root_text.mn128:17.7: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:17.8: Sohaṁ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro’ti.

root_text.mn128:19.6: evameva kho me, anuruddhā, chambhitattaṁ udapādi, chambhitattādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:19.7: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:19.8: Sohaṁ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṁ, na chambhitattan’ti.
root_text.mn128:20.3: ‘uppilaṁ kho me udapādi, uppilādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:20.4: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:20.5: Seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso ekaṁ nidhimukhaṁ gavesanto sakideva pañcanidhimukhāni adhigaccheyya, tassa tatonidānaṁ uppilaṁ uppajjeyya;
root_text.mn128:20.6: evameva kho me, anuruddhā, uppilaṁ udapādi, uppilādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:20.7: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:20.8: Sohaṁ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṁ, na chambhitattaṁ, na uppilan’ti.
root_text.mn128:21.3: ‘duṭṭhullaṁ kho me udapādi, duṭṭhullādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:21.4: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:21.5: Sohaṁ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṁ, na chambhitattaṁ, na uppilaṁ, na duṭṭhullan’ti.
root_text.mn128:22.3: ‘accāraddhavīriyaṁ kho me udapādi, accāraddhavīriyādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:22.4: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:22.5: Seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso ubhohi hatthehi vaṭṭakaṁ gāḷhaṁ gaṇheyya, so tattheva patameyya;
root_text.mn128:22.6: evameva kho me, anuruddhā, accāraddhavīriyaṁ udapādi, accāraddhavīriyādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:22.7: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:22.8: Sohaṁ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṁ, na chambhitattaṁ, na uppilaṁ, na duṭṭhullaṁ, na accāraddhavīriyan’ti.
root_text.mn128:23.3: ‘atilīnavīriyaṁ kho me udapādi, atilīnavīriyādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:23.4: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:23.5: Seyyathāpi, anuruddhā, puriso vaṭṭakaṁ sithilaṁ gaṇheyya, so tassa hatthato uppateyya;
root_text.mn128:23.6: evameva kho me, anuruddhā, atilīnavīriyaṁ udapādi, atilīnavīriyādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:23.7: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:23.8: Sohaṁ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṁ, na chambhitattaṁ, na uppilaṁ, na duṭṭhullaṁ, na accāraddhavīriyaṁ, na atilīnavīriyan’ti.
root_text.mn128:24.3: ‘abhijappā kho me udapādi, abhijappādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:24.4: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:24.5: Sohaṁ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṁ, na chambhitattaṁ, na uppilaṁ, na duṭṭhullaṁ, na accāraddhavīriyaṁ, na atilīnavīriyaṁ, na abhijappā’ti.
root_text.mn128:25.3: ‘nānattasaññā kho me udapādi, nānattasaññādhikaraṇañca pana me samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:25.4: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:25.5: Sohaṁ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṁ, na chambhitattaṁ, na uppilaṁ, na duṭṭhullaṁ, na accāraddhavīriyaṁ, na atilīnavīriyaṁ, na abhijappā, na nānattasaññā’ti.
root_text.mn128:26.1: So kho ahaṁ, anuruddhā, appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto obhāsañceva sañjānāmi dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:26.2: So kho pana me obhāso nacirasseva antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:26.4: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yena me obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānan’ti.
root_text.mn128:26.6: ‘atinijjhāyitattaṁ kho me rūpānaṁ udapādi, atinijjhāyitattādhikaraṇañca pana me rūpānaṁ samādhi cavi.
root_text.mn128:26.7: Samādhimhi cute obhāso antaradhāyati dassanañca rūpānaṁ.
root_text.mn128:26.8: Sohaṁ tathā karissāmi yathā me puna na vicikicchā uppajjissati, na amanasikāro, na thinamiddhaṁ, na chambhitattaṁ, na uppilaṁ, na duṭṭhullaṁ, na accāraddhavīriyaṁ, na atilīnavīriyaṁ, na abhijappā, na nānattasaññā, na atinijjhāyitattaṁ rūpānan’ti.
root_text.mn128:27.1: So kho ahaṁ, anuruddhā, ‘vicikicchā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā vicikicchaṁ cittassa upakkilesaṁ pajahiṁ,
root_text.mn128:27.2: ‘amanasikāro cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā amanasikāraṁ cittassa upakkilesaṁ pajahiṁ,
root_text.mn128:27.3: ‘thinamiddhaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā thinamiddhaṁ cittassa upakkilesaṁ pajahiṁ,
root_text.mn128:27.4: ‘chambhitattaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā chambhitattaṁ cittassa upakkilesaṁ pajahiṁ,
root_text.mn128:27.5: ‘uppilaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā uppilaṁ cittassa upakkilesaṁ pajahiṁ,
root_text.mn128:27.6: ‘duṭṭhullaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā duṭṭhullaṁ cittassa upakkilesaṁ pajahiṁ,
root_text.mn128:27.7: ‘accāraddhavīriyaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā accāraddhavīriyaṁ cittassa upakkilesaṁ pajahiṁ,
root_text.mn128:27.8: ‘atilīnavīriyaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā atilīnavīriyaṁ cittassa upakkilesaṁ pajahiṁ,
root_text.mn128:27.9: ‘abhijappā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā abhijappaṁ cittassa upakkilesaṁ pajahiṁ,
root_text.mn128:27.10: ‘nānattasaññā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā nānattasaññaṁ cittassa upakkilesaṁ pajahiṁ,
root_text.mn128:27.11: ‘atinijjhāyitattaṁ rūpānaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā atinijjhāyitattaṁ rūpānaṁ cittassa upakkilesaṁ pajahiṁ.
root_text.mn128:28.1: So kho ahaṁ, anuruddhā, appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto obhāsañhi kho sañjānāmi, na ca rūpāni passāmi;
root_text.mn128:28.2: rūpāni hi kho passāmi, na ca obhāsaṁ sañjānāmi:
root_text.mn128:28.5: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yvāhaṁ obhāsañhi kho sañjānāmi na ca rūpāni passāmi;
root_text.mn128:28.6: rūpāni hi kho passāmi na ca obhāsaṁ sañjānāmi—
root_text.mn128:28.7: kevalampi rattiṁ, kevalampi divaṁ, kevalampi rattindivan’ti.
root_text.mn128:28.9: ‘yasmiñhi kho ahaṁ samaye rūpanimittaṁ amanasikaritvā obhāsanimittaṁ manasi karomi, obhāsañhi kho tasmiṁ samaye sañjānāmi, na ca rūpāni passāmi.
root_text.mn128:28.10: Yasmiṁ panāhaṁ samaye obhāsanimittaṁ amanasikaritvā rūpanimittaṁ manasi karomi, rūpāni hi kho tasmiṁ samaye passāmi na ca obhāsaṁ sañjānāmi—
root_text.mn128:28.11: kevalampi rattiṁ, kevalampi divaṁ, kevalampi rattindivan’ti.
root_text.mn128:29.1: So kho ahaṁ, anuruddhā, appamatto ātāpī pahitatto viharanto parittañceva obhāsaṁ sañjānāmi, parittāni ca rūpāni passāmi;
root_text.mn128:29.2: appamāṇañceva obhāsaṁ sañjānāmi, appamāṇāni ca rūpāni passāmi:
root_text.mn128:29.5: ‘ko nu kho hetu ko paccayo yvāhaṁ parittañceva obhāsaṁ sañjānāmi, parittāni ca rūpāni passāmi;
root_text.mn128:29.6: appamāṇañceva obhāsaṁ sañjānāmi, appamāṇāni ca rūpāni passāmi—
root_text.mn128:29.7: kevalampi rattiṁ, kevalampi divaṁ, kevalampi rattindivan’ti.
root_text.mn128:29.9: ‘yasmiṁ kho me samaye paritto samādhi hoti, parittaṁ me tasmiṁ samaye cakkhu hoti.
root_text.mn128:29.10: Sohaṁ parittena cakkhunā parittañceva obhāsaṁ sañjānāmi, parittāni ca rūpāni passāmi.
root_text.mn128:29.11: Yasmiṁ pana me samaye appamāṇo samādhi hoti, appamāṇaṁ me tasmiṁ samaye cakkhu hoti.
root_text.mn128:29.12: Sohaṁ appamāṇena cakkhunā appamāṇañceva obhāsaṁ sañjānāmi, appamāṇāni ca rūpāni passāmi—
root_text.mn128:29.13: kevalampi rattiṁ, kevalampi divaṁ, kevalampi rattindivan’ti.
root_text.mn128:30.1: Yato kho me, anuruddhā, ‘vicikicchā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā vicikicchā cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,
root_text.mn128:30.2: ‘amanasikāro cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā amanasikāro cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,
root_text.mn128:30.3: ‘thinamiddhaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā thinamiddhaṁ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,
root_text.mn128:30.4: ‘chambhitattaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā chambhitattaṁ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,
root_text.mn128:30.5: ‘uppilaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā uppilaṁ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,
root_text.mn128:30.6: ‘duṭṭhullaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā duṭṭhullaṁ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,
root_text.mn128:30.7: ‘accāraddhavīriyaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā accāraddhavīriyaṁ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,
root_text.mn128:30.8: ‘atilīnavīriyaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā atilīnavīriyaṁ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,
root_text.mn128:30.9: ‘abhijappā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā abhijappā cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,
root_text.mn128:30.10: ‘nānattasaññā cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā nānattasaññā cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi,
root_text.mn128:30.11: ‘atinijjhāyitattaṁ rūpānaṁ cittassa upakkileso’ti—iti viditvā atinijjhāyitattaṁ rūpānaṁ cittassa upakkileso pahīno ahosi.
root_text.mn128:31.2: ‘ye kho me cittassa upakkilesā te me pahīnā.
root_text.mn128:31.4: So kho ahaṁ, anuruddhā, savitakkampi savicāraṁ samādhiṁ bhāvesiṁ, avitakkampi vicāramattaṁ samādhiṁ bhāvesiṁ, avitakkampi avicāraṁ samādhiṁ bhāvesiṁ, sappītikampi samādhiṁ bhāvesiṁ, nippītikampi samādhiṁ bhāvesiṁ, sātasahagatampi samādhiṁ bhāvesiṁ, upekkhāsahagatampi samādhiṁ bhāvesiṁ.
root_text.mn128:32.1: Yato kho me, anuruddhā, savitakkopi savicāro samādhi bhāvito ahosi, avitakkopi vicāramatto samādhi bhāvito ahosi, avitakkopi avicāro samādhi bhāvito ahosi, sappītikopi samādhi bhāvito ahosi, nippītikopi samādhi bhāvito ahosi, sātasahagatopi samādhi bhāvito ahosi, upekkhāsahagatopi samādhi bhāvito ahosi.
root_text.mn128:32.3: akuppā me cetovimutti. Ayamantimā jāti, natthi dāni punabbhavo”ti.
root_text.mn128:32.5: Attamano āyasmā anuruddho bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.

translation_text.mn128:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
translation_text.mn128:2.1: Now at that time the mendicants of Kosambī were fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
translation_text.mn128:3.1: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and told him what was happening, adding:
translation_text.mn128:3.3: “Please, sir go to those mendicants out of sympathy.”
translation_text.mn128:4.1: Then the Buddha went up to those mendicants and said,
translation_text.mn128:4.2: “Enough, mendicants! Stop fighting, quarreling, and disputing.”
translation_text.mn128:4.3: When he said this, one of the mendicants said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn128:4.5: Let the Buddha, the Lord of the Dhamma,
translation_text.mn128:4.6: remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in this life.
translation_text.mn128:4.7: We will be known for this fighting, quarreling, arguing, and disputing.”
translation_text.mn128:4.15: and a third time the Buddha said to those mendicants,
translation_text.mn128:4.16: “Enough, mendicants! Stop fighting, quarreling, and disputing.”
translation_text.mn128:4.17: For a third time that mendicant said to the Buddha,
translation_text.mn128:4.19: Let the Buddha, the Lord of the Dhamma,
translation_text.mn128:4.20: remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in this life.
translation_text.mn128:4.21: We will be known for this fighting, quarreling, arguing, and disputing.”
translation_text.mn128:5.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kosambī for alms.
translation_text.mn128:5.2: After the meal, on his return from almsround, he set his lodgings in order. Taking his bowl and robe, he recited these verses while standing right there:
translation_text.mn128:6.2: yet no-one thinks that they’re the fool.
translation_text.mn128:6.4: they think no better of the other.
translation_text.mn128:6.6: they talk, their words out of bounds.
translation_text.mn128:6.7: They blab at will, their mouths agape,
translation_text.mn128:6.8: and not one knows what leads them on.
translation_text.mn128:6.10: They beat me, they robbed me!’
translation_text.mn128:6.11: For those bearing such a grudge,
translation_text.mn128:6.12: hatred is never laid to rest.
translation_text.mn128:6.14: They beat me, they robbed me!’
translation_text.mn128:6.15: For those who bear no such grudge,
translation_text.mn128:6.19: it’s laid to rest by love:
translation_text.mn128:6.22: let us, who do understand this,
translation_text.mn128:6.24: for that is how conflicts are laid to rest.
translation_text.mn128:6.25: Breakers of bones and takers of life,
translation_text.mn128:6.30: If you find an alert companion,
translation_text.mn128:6.31: an attentive friend to live happily together,
translation_text.mn128:6.33: wander with them, joyful and mindful.
translation_text.mn128:6.34: If you find no alert companion,
translation_text.mn128:6.35: no attentive friend to live happily together,
translation_text.mn128:6.36: then, like a king who flees his conquered realm,
translation_text.mn128:6.37: wander alone like a tusker in the wilds.
translation_text.mn128:6.40: Wander alone and do no wrong,
translation_text.mn128:6.41: at ease like a tusker in the wilds.”
translation_text.mn128:7.1: After speaking these verses while standing, the Buddha went to the village of the child salt-miners,
translation_text.mn128:7.2: where Venerable Bhagu was staying at the time.
translation_text.mn128:7.3: Bhagu saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
translation_text.mn128:7.4: so he spread out a seat and placed water for washing the feet.
translation_text.mn128:7.5: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out,
translation_text.mn128:7.7: Bhagu bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
translation_text.mn128:7.9: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you’re having no trouble getting almsfood.”
translation_text.mn128:7.10: “I’m keeping well, Blessed One; I’m all right. And I’m having no trouble getting almsfood.”
translation_text.mn128:7.11: Then the Buddha educated, encouraged, fired up, and inspired Bhagu with a Dhamma talk, after which he got up from his seat and set out for the Park of the East-Raftered Hall.
translation_text.mn128:8.1: Now at that time the venerables Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila were staying in the Park of the East-Raftered Hall.
translation_text.mn128:8.2: The park keeper saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
translation_text.mn128:8.5: There are three gentlemen staying here whose nature is to desire only the self.
translation_text.mn128:9.1: Anuruddha heard the park keeper conversing with the Buddha,
translation_text.mn128:9.3: “Don’t keep the Buddha out, good park keeper!
translation_text.mn128:9.4: Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived.”
translation_text.mn128:10.1: Then Anuruddha went to Nandiya and Kimbila, and said to them,
translation_text.mn128:10.2: “Come forth, venerables, come forth! Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived!”
translation_text.mn128:10.3: Then Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila came out to greet the Buddha.
translation_text.mn128:10.4: One received his bowl and robe, one spread out a seat, and one set out water for washing his feet.
translation_text.mn128:10.5: The Buddha sat on the seat spread out
translation_text.mn128:10.7: Those venerables bowed and sat down to one side.
translation_text.mn128:10.9: “I hope you’re keeping well, Anuruddha and friends; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you’re having no trouble getting almsfood.”
translation_text.mn128:10.10: “We’re keeping well, Blessed One; we’re all right. And we’re having no trouble getting almsfood.”
translation_text.mn128:11.1: “I hope you’re living in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes?”
translation_text.mn128:11.2: “Indeed, sir, we live in harmony as you say.”
translation_text.mn128:11.3: “But how do you live this way?”
translation_text.mn128:12.3: to live together with spiritual companions such as these.’
translation_text.mn128:12.4: I consistently treat these venerables with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
translation_text.mn128:12.8: ‘Why don’t I set aside my own ideas and just go along with these venerables’ ideas?’
translation_text.mn128:12.10: Though we’re different in body, sir, we’re one in mind, it seems to me.”
translation_text.mn128:12.11: And the venerables Nandiya and Kimbila spoke likewise, and they added:
translation_text.mn128:12.23: “That’s how we live in harmony, appreciating each other, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.”
translation_text.mn128:13.2: But I hope you’re living diligently, keen, and resolute?”
translation_text.mn128:14.2: “But how do you live this way?”
translation_text.mn128:14.3: “In this case, sir, whoever returns first from almsround prepares the seats, and puts out the drinking water and the rubbish bin.
translation_text.mn128:14.4: If there’s anything left over, whoever returns last eats it if they like. Otherwise they throw it out where there is little that grows, or drop it into water that has no living creatures.
translation_text.mn128:14.5: Then they put away the seats, drinking water, and rubbish bin, and sweep the refectory.
translation_text.mn128:14.6: If someone sees that the pot of water for washing, drinking, or the toilet is empty they set it up.
translation_text.mn128:14.7: If he can’t do it, he summons another with a wave of the hand, and they set it up by lending each other a hand to lift. But we don’t break into speech for that reason.
translation_text.mn128:14.8: And every five days we sit together for the whole night and discuss the teachings.
translation_text.mn128:14.9: That’s how we live diligently, keen, and resolute.”
translation_text.mn128:15.2: But as you live diligently like this, have you achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a comfortable meditation?”
translation_text.mn128:15.3: “Well, sir, while meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, we perceive both light and vision of forms.
translation_text.mn128:15.4: But before long the light and the vision of forms vanish.
translation_text.mn128:15.5: We haven’t worked out the basis of that.”
translation_text.mn128:16.1: “Well, you should work out the basis of that.
translation_text.mn128:16.2: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too perceived light and vision of forms.
translation_text.mn128:16.3: But before long my light and vision of forms vanished.
translation_text.mn128:16.5: ‘What’s the cause, what’s the reason why my light and vision of forms vanish?’
translation_text.mn128:16.7: ‘Doubt arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
translation_text.mn128:16.8: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.
translation_text.mn128:16.9: I’ll make sure that doubt will not arise in me again.’
translation_text.mn128:17.1: While meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, I perceived light and vision of forms.
translation_text.mn128:17.2: But before long my light and vision of forms vanished.
translation_text.mn128:17.4: ‘What’s the cause, what’s the reason why my light and vision of forms vanish?’
translation_text.mn128:17.6: ‘Loss of focus arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
translation_text.mn128:17.7: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.
translation_text.mn128:17.8: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus will arise in me again.’
translation_text.mn128:18.5: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness will arise in me again.’
translation_text.mn128:19.3: ‘Terror arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
translation_text.mn128:19.4: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.
translation_text.mn128:19.5: Suppose a person was traveling along a road, and killers were to spring out at them from both sides. They’d feel terrified because of that.
translation_text.mn128:19.6: In the same way, terror arose in me …
translation_text.mn128:19.8: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror will arise in me again.’
translation_text.mn128:20.3: ‘Elation arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
translation_text.mn128:20.4: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.
translation_text.mn128:20.5: Suppose a person was looking for the entrance to a treasure trove. And all at once they’d come across five entrances! They’d feel excited because of that.
translation_text.mn128:20.6: In the same way, elation arose in me …
translation_text.mn128:20.8: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation will arise in me again.’
translation_text.mn128:21.5: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort will arise in me again.’
translation_text.mn128:22.3: ‘Excessive energy arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
translation_text.mn128:22.4: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.
translation_text.mn128:22.5: Suppose a person was to grip a quail too tightly in their hands—it would die right there.
translation_text.mn128:22.8: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort nor excessive energy will arise in me again.’
translation_text.mn128:23.3: ‘Overly lax energy arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
translation_text.mn128:23.4: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.
translation_text.mn128:23.5: Suppose a person was to grip a quail too loosely—it would fly out of their hands.
translation_text.mn128:23.8: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort nor excessive energy nor overly lax energy will arise in me again.’
translation_text.mn128:24.5: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort nor excessive energy nor overly lax energy nor longing will arise in me again.’
translation_text.mn128:25.5: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort nor excessive energy nor overly lax energy nor longing nor perception of diversity will arise in me again.’
translation_text.mn128:26.1: While meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, I perceived light and vision of forms.
translation_text.mn128:26.2: But before long my light and vision of forms vanished.
translation_text.mn128:26.4: ‘What’s the cause, what’s the reason why my light and vision of forms vanish?’
translation_text.mn128:26.6: ‘Excessive concentration on forms arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
translation_text.mn128:26.7: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.
translation_text.mn128:26.8: I’ll make sure that neither doubt nor loss of focus nor dullness and drowsiness nor terror nor elation nor discomfort nor excessive energy nor overly lax energy nor longing nor perception of diversity nor excessive concentration on forms will arise in me again.’
translation_text.mn128:27.1: When I understood that doubt is a corruption of the mind, I gave it up.
translation_text.mn128:27.2: When I understood that loss of focus,
translation_text.mn128:27.11: and excessive concentration on forms are corruptions of the mind, I gave them up.
translation_text.mn128:28.1: While meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, I perceived light but did not see forms,
translation_text.mn128:28.2: or I saw forms, but did not see light.
translation_text.mn128:28.3: And this went on for a whole night, a whole day, even a whole night and day.
translation_text.mn128:28.5: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason for this?’
translation_text.mn128:28.9: ‘When I don’t focus on the basis of the forms, but focus on the basis of the light, then I perceive light and do not see forms.
translation_text.mn128:28.10: But when I don’t focus on the basis of the light, but focus on the basis of the forms, then I see forms and do not perceive light.
translation_text.mn128:28.11: And this goes on for a whole night, a whole day, even a whole night and day.’
translation_text.mn128:29.1: While meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, I perceived limited light and saw limited forms,
translation_text.mn128:29.2: or I perceived limitless light and saw limitless forms.
translation_text.mn128:29.3: And this went on for a whole night, a whole day, even a whole night and day.
translation_text.mn128:29.5: ‘What is the cause, what is the reason for this?’
translation_text.mn128:29.9: ‘When my immersion is limited, then my vision is limited,
translation_text.mn128:29.10: and with limited vision I perceive limited light and see limited forms.
translation_text.mn128:29.11: But when my immersion is limitless, then my vision is limitless,
translation_text.mn128:29.12: and with limitless vision I perceive limitless light and see limitless forms.
translation_text.mn128:29.13: And this goes on for a whole night, a whole day, even a whole night and day.’
translation_text.mn128:30.11: and excessive concentration on forms are corruptions of the mind, I had given them up.
translation_text.mn128:31.3: Now let me develop immersion in three ways.’
translation_text.mn128:31.4: I developed immersion while placing the mind and keeping it connected; without placing the mind, merely keeping it connected; without placing the mind or keeping it connected; with rapture; without rapture; with pleasure; with equanimity.
translation_text.mn128:32.1: When I had developed immersion in these ways,
translation_text.mn128:32.2: the knowledge and vision arose in me:
translation_text.mn128:32.3: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”
translation_text.mn128:32.4: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn128:32.5: Satisfied, Venerable Anuruddha approved what the Buddha said.
